title: Shelford Walks

images.title: Tim Heaton / Seat and millennium stone on road through Shelford
images.caption: Seat and millennium stone on road through Shelford. The stone is a rather incongruous lump of granite, inscribed 'Shelford 2000'. Waterlane Farm behind, with the date 1834 in the brickwork, is one of several farms in the area belonging to the Crown Estate.

images.title: Tim Heaton / The Earl of Chesterfield, Shelford
images.caption: The Earl of Chesterfield. Philip Stanhope of Shelford was created first Earl of Chesterfield by Charles I in 1628. His support of the Royalists led to a significant battle at Shelford Manor in the Civil War.

images.title: Tom Courtney / Church Street, Shelford Village
images.caption: Church Street, Shelford Village

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Shelford War Memorial
images.caption: Shelford War Memorial. At the junction of West Street and Main Road.

images.title: Tim Heaton / Shelford Hill
images.caption: The road, Shelford Hill, leading up from the valley of the Trent. Burton Joyce sits on the horizon among trees on the far, northern bank of the Trent. The hill is located just to the south of the village.

images.title: Tim Heaton / Climbing Shelford Hill
images.caption: Climbing Shelford Hill - to the east of the village. The Trent Valley Way momentarily leaving the flood plain of the Trent for higher ground. The Way follows the hedgerows to the small plantation on the horizon (right of centre), before turning left to follow the ridge to East Bridgford.

images.title: Tim Heaton / Trent Valley Way rejoining theTrent
images.caption: Trent Valley Way. rejoining theTrent Having left the banks of the Trent at Holme Pierrepont, about 4 miles upstream, the TVW rejoins on the flood embankment near Stoke Bardolph.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Finger ponds
images.caption: Finger ponds. This is the name given to the area of former gravel workings at the eastern end of Holme Pierrepont Country Park. It derives from the way that this area was worked leaving long narrow strips of water divided by narrow banks. The formation shows up better on the 1:25000 maps than on the 1:50000.

description: This attractive Nottinghamshire village has some nice river and country trails to try. It sits in a fine rural spot just a couple of miles east of Nottingham. This walk from the village takes you to the nearby Holme Pierrepont Country Park along the Trent Valley Way. The walk starts in the village and heads west to the river where you can pick up the Trent Valley Way, opposite Stoke Bardolph. Follow the waymarked footpath south and it will take you past Radcliffe on Trent to Holme Pierrepont Park. Here you'll find a nature reserve, a number of lakes and the National Watersports Centre. On the opposite side of the river there's more nice waterside trails in Colwick Country Park near West Bridgford. The route returns to the village on the same paths though you could take a small detour to climb Shelford Hill to the south of the settlement. There are nice views over the area from this elevated spot.
